description: From Medieval Latin sexagesimalis, from sexāgēsimus (“sixtieth”) + -ālis (“-al”), from sexāgintā (“sixty”). Cognate with sexagenary and sexagenarian. Cf. sextal.

entries.meaning: (mathematics) Of, related to, or based on the number sixty.
examples: The common English divisions of time, longitude, and latitude are all computed using sexagesimal arithmetic.

entries.meaning: (mathematics) A fraction involving division by 60; a sixtieth part of something.
examples: Decimals are actually less convenient than sexagesimals for working with most common fractions.
Babylonian mathematics was computed in sexagesimals.
